DA4BCI 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Manifold-based Multi-step Domain Adaptation (M3D)

    domain_adaptation_m3d.Rd

    The domain_adaptation_m3d function performs two-stage manifold-based domain adaptation using a dynamic distribution alignment strategy. It first reduces domain discrepancy via kernel-based or subspace-based alignment (e.g., TCA, SA), followed by iterative refinement of class-aware alignment with pseudo-labels.

    domain_adaptation_m3d(
  source_data,
  source_labels,
  target_data,
  stage1 = list(method = "tca", control = list(k = NULL, sigma = 1)),
  stage2 = list(method = "sa", control = list(k = 10)),
  l_iter = 10,
  lambda_ridge = 0.01,
  eta_kernel = 0.1,
  label_offset = 0,
  expl_var = 0.9,
  max_dim = 30
)

    Arguments

    source_data

    A numeric matrix representing the source domain (rows = samples, columns = features).

    source_labels

    A factor or vector of class labels for the source domain.

    target_data

    A numeric matrix representing the target domain with the same number of columns as source_data.

    stage1

    A list specifying the method and control parameters for the first alignment stage (e.g., TCA, PCA). Default: list(method = "tca", control = list(k = NULL, sigma = 1)).

    stage2

    A list specifying the method and control parameters for the second alignment stage (e.g., SA). Default: list(method = "sa", control = list(k = 10)).

    l_iter

    Number of iterations for label refinement and class-wise alignment. Default: 10.

    lambda_ridge

    Regularization strength for the ridge regression step. Default: 1e-2.

    eta_kernel

    Weight for class-aware kernel alignment term. Default: 0.1.

    label_offset

    Optional offset to shift the pseudo-labels. Default: 0.

    expl_var

    Explained variance threshold (used in PCA-based dimension selection). Default: 0.90.

    max_dim

    Maximum cap for automatically selected subspace dimension. Default: 30.

    Value

    A list with:

    weighted_source_data

    The aligned source features after two-stage transformation and M3D refinement.

    target_data

    The aligned target features in the same latent manifold space.

    Details

    Multi-step Manifold Alignment with Dynamic Distribution (M3D) proceeds as:

    1. Use stage-1 transformation (e.g., TCA) to reduce marginal domain shift.

    2. Apply optional stage-2 transformation (e.g., SA) to further align subspaces.

    3. Construct a kernel matrix over aligned features and apply a class-aware MMD penalty using pseudo-labels for the target domain.

    4. Iteratively update pseudo-labels via ridge regression and recompute dynamic alignment matrices.

    5. Perform eigen-decomposition on the final kernel matrix to extract features in the aligned manifold space.

    This implementation is based on the M3D framework proposed in: Luo, T. et al. (2024). M3D: Manifold-based domain adaptation with dynamic distribution for non-deep transfer learning in cross-subject and cross-session EEG-based emotion recognition. arXiv preprint arXiv:2404.15615.

    References

    Luo, T., Zhang, J., Qiu, Y., Zhang, L., Hu, Y., Yu, Z., & Liang, Z. (2024). M3D: Manifold-based domain adaptation with dynamic distribution for non-deep transfer learning in cross-subject and cross-session EEG-based emotion recognition. arXiv preprint arXiv:2404.15615.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
set.seed(1)
src <- matrix(rnorm(100 * 20), nrow = 100)
tgt <- matrix(rnorm(100 * 20, mean = 1), nrow = 100)
labels <- sample(1:3, 100, replace = TRUE)
out <- domain_adaptation_m3d(src, labels, tgt)
str(out$weighted_source_data)
str(out$target_data)
} # }
